prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC3256 - HCN, HCO+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of HCN, HCO+ in Band 3 towards the outflow of NGC3256

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
HCN and HCO+(1-0) can be observed in the same baseband, centred at the HCN frequency.
The average velocity of the outflows is 250 km/s (Sakamoto et al 2006, 2014). We will average the spectra to four channels, and will work on a final frequency resolution of 40 km/s

NGC3256 has a double nucleus with two bipolar molecular outflows. Both outflows have an extent of 5" (Sakamoto et al. 2014), which we DO NOT aim to resolve. We ask for a 1" resolution, which is enough to study the chemistry in the outflows and their properties as a function of the driving source and outflow velocity.

We propose to observe HCN and HCO+(1-0) in the outflows of the luminous merger NGC3256. These transitions are free of contamining lines of vibrationally excited HCN, HC3N, CH3CN and CH3OH - lines that Aalto et al (2015 submitted) are finding to be bright in the line wings of higher HCN and HCO+ transitions.
Sakamoto et al. 2014 used ALMA to detect CO(1-0), CN(1-0) and HCO+(3-2) in the two outflows of NGC3256 with a resolution of 2.7", 1.5", 0.6" respectively. From CO(1-0), we calculate the expected fluxes of HCN and HCO+(1-0) at the proposed resolution of 1", assuming that all three molecules arise from the same extent, and a line ratio HCN/CO=0.01. We expect to detect an outflow signature of these two species of 5 mJy. We aim at a S/N=10, so we ask for a rms of 0.5 mJy.
Given the broad linewidths of the detected species in the outflow of NGC3256 (~250 km/s), we can calculate the rms in a broad bandwidth of 40 km/s.
We have used the ALMA time estimator and find that we need 23 min on source (for 40km/s resolution). The time time with calibration and overheads is 48 min.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC3256 - CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of CN (1-0) in Band 3 towards the outflow of NGC3256

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The average velocity of the outflows is 250 km/s (Sakamoto et al 2006, 2014). We will average the spectra to four channels, and will work on a final frequency resolution of 40 km/s

NGC3256 has a double nucleus with two bipolar molecular outflows. Both outflows have an extent of 5" (Sakamoto et al. 2014), which we DO NOT aim to resolve. We ask for a 1" resolution, which is enough to study the chemistry in the outflows and their properties as a function of the driving source and outflow velocity.

We propose to observe CN(1-0) in the outflows of the luminous merger NGC3256.
Sakamoto et al. 2014 used ALMA to detect CO(1-0), CN(1-0) and HCO+(3-2) in the two outflows of NGC3256 with a resolution of 2.7", 1.5", 0.6" respectively. From this, we calculate the expected flux of CN(1-0) at the proposed resolution of 1", assuming that CN and CO arise from the same region (same source sizes), and a CN/CO ratio of 0.08. We expect to detect an outflow signature of this species of 5 mJy. We aim at a S/N=10, so we ask for a rms of 0.5 mJy.
Given the broad linewidths of the detected species in the outflow of NGC3256 (~250 km/s), we can calculate the rms in a broad bandwidth of 40 km/s.
We have used the ALMA time estimator and find that we need 29 min on source (for 40km/s resolution). The time time with calibration and overheads is 54 min.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC3628 - HCN, HCO+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to detec HCN and HCO+(1-0) in the outflow of NGC3628

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
HCN and HCO+(1-0) can be observed in the same baseband, centred at the HCN frequency.
The average velocity of the outflow is 200 km/s (Tsai et al 2012). We will average the spectra to four channels, and will work on a final frequency resolution of 20 km/s, so we will have ~10 channels per line.

NGC3628 has a outflow of extent 370-450 pc, equivalent to 10-12" ( Tsai et al. 2012), which we DO NOT aim to resolve. We ask for a 1" resolution, which is enough to study the chemistry in the outflows and their properties as a function of the driving source and outflow velocity.

We propose to observe HCN and HCO+(1-0) in the outflow of the galaxy NGC3628. These transitions are free of contamining lines of vibrationally excited HCN, HC3N, CH3CN and CH3OH - lines that Aalto et al (2015 submitted) are fingind to be bright in the line wings of higher HCN and HCO+ transitions.
Tsai et al. 2012 detected CO(1-0) in the outflow of NGC3628 with a resolution of ~3.01"x 2.36" with the Nobeyama Millimeter Array. They obtained a CO(1-0) integrated flux of 82 Jy km/s. From that, we calculated the HCN and HCO+(1-0) fluxes assuming the same source size as CO and a HCN/CO line ratio of 0.1. We expect to find a wing intensity of ~75 mJy for both HCN and HCO+. A sensitivity of 7mJy would give us a S/N=10
We have used the ALMA time estimator and find that we need 2 min on source (for 20 km/s resolution). The total time with calibration and overheads is 21.66 min.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC3628 - CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to detec CN(1-0) in the outflow of NGC3628

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The average velocity of the outflow is 200 km/s (Tsai et al 2012). We will average the spectra to four channels, and will work on a final frequency resolution of 20 km/s, so we will have ~10 channels per line.

NGC3628 has a outflow of extent 370-450 pc, equivalent to 10-12" ( Tsai et al. 2012), which we DO NOT aim to resolve. We ask for a 1" resolution, which is enough to study the chemistry in the outflows and their properties as a function of the driving source and outflow velocity.

We propose to observe CN(1-0) in the outflow of the galaxy NGC3628.
Tsai et al. 2012 detected CO(1-0) in the outflow of NGC3628 with a resolution of ~3.01"x 2.36" with the Nobeyama Millimeter Array. They obtained a CO(1-0) integrated flux of 82 Jy km/s. From that, we calculated the CN(1-0) flux assuming the same source size as CO and a CN/CO line ratio of 0.08. We expect to find a wing intensity of ~50 mJy. A sensitivity of 5 mJy would give us a S/N=10
We have used the ALMA time estimator and find that we need 2 min on source (for 20 km/s resolution). The total time with calibration and overheads is 32.50 min.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC1377 - HCN, HCO+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to detec HCN and HCO+(1-0) in the outflow of NGC1377

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
HCN and HCO+(1-0) can be observed in the same baseband, centred at the HCN frequency.
The average velocity of the outflow is 200 km/s (Aalto et al 2012). We will average the spectra to four channels, and will work on a final frequency resolution of 40 km/s.

NGC1377 has a outflow of extent 2" (Aalto et al. 2012), which we DO NOT aim to resolve. We ask for a 1" resolution, which is enough to study the chemistry in the outflows and their properties as a function of the driving source and outflow velocity.

We propose to observe HCN and HCO+(1-0) in the outflow of the radio-quite FIR excess galaxy NGC1377. These transitions are free of contamining lines of vibrationally excited HCN, HC3N, CH3CN and CH3OH - lines that Aalto et al (2015 submitted) are fingind to be bright in the line wings of higher HCN and HCO+ transitions.
Aalto et al. 2012 detected CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) in the outflow of NGC1377 with a resolution of ~0.5" and ~3.5" respectively. To estimate the total CO(1-0) flux we assumed thermalised optically think CO emission, i.e. L[CO(1-0)] = L(CO(2-1)) (Somolon & Vanden Bout 2005, Cicone et al. 2013). From that, we calculated the HCN(1-0) flux assuming the same source size as CO and a HCN/CO line ratio of 0.1. We expect to find a wing intensity of ~4mJy for both HCN and HCO+. A sensitivity of 0.5mJy would give us a S/N=8.
We have used the ALMA time estimator and find that we need 22 min on source (for 40 km/s resolution). The to9tal time with calibration and overheads is 46.02 min.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC1377 - CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We want to detec CN(1-0) in the outflow of NGC1377

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The average velocity of the outflow is 200 km/s (Aalto et al 2012). We will average the spectra to four channels, and will work on a final frequency resolution of 40 km/s. This will give us ~5 channels per line.

NGC1377 has a outflow of extent 2" (Aalto et al. 2012), which we DO NOT aim to resolve. We ask for a 1" resolution, which is enough to study the chemistry in the outflows and their properties as a function of the driving source and outflow velocity.

We propose to observe CN(1-0) in the outflow of the radio-quite FIR excess galaxy NGC1377.
Aalto et al. 2012 detected CO(2-1) and 13CO(2-1) in the outflow of NGC1377 with a resolution of ~0.5" and ~3.5" respectively. To estimate the total CN(1-0) flux we assumed thermalised optically think CO emission, i.e. L[CO(1-0)] = L(CO(2-1)) (Somolon & Vanden Bout 2005, Cicone et al. 2013). From that, we calculated the CN(1-0) flux assuming the same source size as CO and a CN/CO line ratio of 0.08. We expect to find a wing intensity of ~3mJy. A sensitivity of 0.5mJy would give us a S/N=6.
We have used the ALMA time estimator and find that we need 29 min on source (for 40 km/s resolution). The total time with calibration and overheads is 52.90 min.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Powerful outflows regulate star formation as well as super massive black hole accretion and grow through negative feedback in active galaxies. By removing the gas available for star formation, they quench the galaxy activity and impact on galaxy evolution. However, the properties of the outflowing gas are still poorly known. We do not know if and how the cloud properties change going from circumnuclear disks clouds into the winds, and how this relates to the nature of the driving source.
We propose a study of HCN, HCO+ and CN (1-0) in a set of three galaxies showing outflows with very different characteristics. We include both fast and slow speed outflows and starburst and AGN driving sources. We aim to explain: (i) how much dense gas is being carried out in the outflows, and if the fraction of dense gas depends on the driving source; (ii) How much star formation is taking place in the outflows; and (iii) how does the speed of the outflow affect its structure (i.e. how long can the dense gas travel before being evaporated or forming stars).
Thanks to ALMA, we are opening up new avenues in addressing the origin and fate of molecular gas in galactic outflows using astrochemistry.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
Goddard Space Flight Center, National Aeronautics and Space Administration
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
Classe di Scienze, Pisa, Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa
